title: feat: assert declared elf features are compatible with cpu
body:
This change parses the required RISCV extensions declared in the ".riscv.attributes" elf section and the supported extensions as reported by the SBI firmware through the FDT and asserts that all required extensions are supported on all CPUs.

This PR should be left as a draft for now for future reference, since there is no real point in this assertion right now (we know QEMU supports everything we need). 
This should be reenabled when hardware-bringup is happening, or when long-term caching of intermediate code artifacts on disk becomes a thing (so that - if the CPU has been hot swapped since the artifact had been cached - we can check wether it is still compatible or not).

Either way, this change is for later reference.

TODO

- Currently require all CPUs to support the given executable. We should however, change it so any CPU that supports the payload moves forward, while CPUs not supporting the payload get halted. We could then report to the payload which CPUs have been halted due to extension mismatches. This way the payload can decide what to do (keep the CPUs halted, boot them using a different payload etc.)

title: chore(deps): update rust crate hashbrown to 0.15.0 - autoclosed
body:
This PR contains the following updates:

| Package | Type | Update | Change |
|---|---|---|---|
| [hashbrown](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown) | workspace.dependencies | minor | `0.14.5` -> `0.15.0` |

---

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>rust-lang/hashbrown (hashbrown)</summary>

### [`v0.15.2`](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/blob/HEAD/CHANGELOG.md#v0152---2024-11-14)

##### Added

-   Marked `const fn` constructors as `rustc_const_stable_indirect` when built as
    part of the standard library. ([#​586](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/issues/586))

### [`v0.15.1`](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/blob/HEAD/CHANGELOG.md#v0151---2024-11-03)

[Compare Source](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/compare/v0.15.0...v0.15.1)

This release removes the `borsh` feature introduced in 0.15.0 because it was
found to be incorrectly implemented. Users should use the `hashbrown` feature of
the `borsh` crate instead which provides the same trait implementations.

### [`v0.15.0`](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/blob/HEAD/CHANGELOG.md#-v0150---2024-10-01)

[Compare Source](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/compare/v0.14.5...v0.15.0)

This release was *yanked* due to a broken implementation of the `borsh` feature.

This update contains breaking changes that remove the `raw` API with the hope of
centralising on the `HashTable` API in the future. You can follow the discussion
and progress in [#​545](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/issues/545) to discuss features you think should be added to this API
that were previously only possible on the `raw` API.

##### Added

-   Added `borsh` feature with `BorshSerialize` and `BorshDeserialize` impls. ([#​525](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/issues/525))
-   Added `Assign` impls for `HashSet` operators. ([#​529](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/issues/529))
-   Added `Default` impls for iterator types. ([#​542](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/issues/542))
-   Added `HashTable::iter_hash{,_mut}` methods. ([#​549](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/issues/549))
-   Added `Hash{Table,Map,Set}::allocation_size` methods. ([#​553](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/issues/553))
-   Implemented `Debug` and `FusedIterator` for all `HashTable` iterators. ([#​561](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/issues/561))
-   Specialized `Iterator::fold` for all `HashTable` iterators. ([#​561](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/issues/561))

##### Changed

-   Changed `hash_set::VacantEntry::insert` to return `OccupiedEntry`. ([#​495](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/issues/495))
-   Improved`hash_set::Difference::size_hint` lower-bound. ([#​530](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/issues/530))
-   Improved `HashSet::is_disjoint` performance. ([#​531](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/issues/531))
-   `equivalent` feature is now enabled by default. ([#​532](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/issues/532))
-   `HashSet` operators now return a set with the same allocator. ([#​529](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/issues/529))
-   Changed the default hasher to foldhash. ([#​563](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/issues/563))
-   `ahash` feature has been renamed to `default-hasher`. ([#​533](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/issues/533))
-   Entry API has been reworked and several methods have been renamed. ([#​535](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/issues/535))
-   `Hash{Map,Set}::insert_unique_unchecked` is now unsafe. ([#​556](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/issues/556))
-   The signature of `get_many_mut` and related methods was changed. ([#​562](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/issues/562))

##### Fixed

-   Fixed typos, stray backticks in docs. ([#​558](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/issues/558), [#​560](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/issues/560))

##### Removed

-   Raw entry API is now under `raw-entry` feature, to be eventually removed. ([#​534](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/issues/534), [#​555](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/issues/555))
-   Raw table API has been made private and the `raw` feature is removed;
    in the future, all code should be using the `HashTable` API instead. ([#​531](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/issues/531), [#​546](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/issues/546))
-   `rykv` feature was removed; this is now provided by the `rykv` crate instead. ([#​554](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/issues/554))
-   `HashSet::get_or_insert_owned` was removed in favor of `get_or_insert_with`. ([#​555](https://redirect.github.com/rust-lang/hashbrown/issues/555))

</details>

title: feat: `ksharded-slab`
body: This PR introduces a fork of the `sharded-slab` crate for use in the kernel as a general purpose slab allocator.

title: feat: kernel `tracing` support
body:
Until now, kernel debugging was been limited to structured logging through `log` and while that is great and more than sufficient for release-build logging, for debugging purposes and especially for performance work we need something more sophisticated.

To this end #185 introduced the concept time & initial support for monotonic and wall-time clocks into the kernel, so that we can actually measure things. 

This PR lays the groundwork for more sophisticated debugging by bringing [`tracing`] support to the kernel. [`tracing`] is a standard Rust crate that - in addition to *events* that `log` deals with - knows about *spans* which represent spans of execution between two points in time. Since tracing has been built with asynchronous Rust in mind, spans can also be paused and resumed an arbitrary amount of time (called `entering` and `exiting`) which is convenient for tracking execution time in all kinds of multitasking setups.
[`tracing`] also features a host of convenient macros to emit these spans.

[`tracing`]: https://crates.io/crates/tracing

title: fix(loader/vm): correctly calculate and map TLS regions
body: This change fixes a bug with the TLS mapping code, which caused the kernel TLS region per hart to be incorrectly calculated. By fixing it we also reduced the TLS allocation memory consumption by a factor of ~`PAGE_SIZE` (4096).

commit.message:
fix(loader/vm): correctly calculate and map TLS regions

This change fixes a bug with the TLS mapping code, which caused the kernel TLS region per hart to be incorrectly calculated. By fixing it we also reduced the TLS allocation memory consumption by a factor of ~PAGE_SIZE.

title: chore: QEMU reenable SMP & NUMA
body:
This change reenables SMP in QEMU. The kernel should be fully SMP ready and future development should have SMP enabled to make sure support doesn't regress.

This change also sets up a basic NUMA topology, where 8 cpus are equally grouped into 2 nodes and memory is also equally divided between the two nodes.

commit.message:
chore: QEMU reenable SMP

This change reenables SMP in QEMU. The kernel should be fully SMP ready and future development should have SMP enabled to make sure support doesn't regress.

This change also sets up a basic NUMA topology, where 8 cpus are equally grouped into 2 nodes and memory is also equally divided between the two nodes

title: feat(loader): include guard pages in stack allocations
body: As part of reenabling SMP by default, this change adds guard pages below each harts stack allocation to catch kernel stack overflows.

commit.message:
feat(loader): include guard pages in stack allocations

As part of reenabling SMP by default, this change adds guard pages below each harts stack allocation to catch kernel stack overflows.

title: refactor(loader): remove the (unused) memory mode option

commit.message: refactor(loader): remove the (unused) memory mode option

title: refactor: rework startup sequence
body:
This PR is (another) big overhaul of the startup sequence, but the last one we need for now. This rework removes a few features from the loader, notably multithreading support and stack,tls,heap allocation in favor of letting the kernel decide how to deal with those.
This drastically simplifies the startup sequence and makes the code much easier to read and understand. Multithreading support for bringup of other harts will de delayed until later after the NUMA topology subsystem has been implemented and we actually know how many harts we will have.

This PR also adds a few misc features to the startup sequence:
- probing for supported SBI extensions
- parsing reported supported RISCV features per-hart
- parsing reported sizes for the CBOP, CBOZ and CBOM extensions

commit.message:
chore(loader): report TLS template alignment

This change ammends the `TlsTemplate` struct with a field reporting the chosen alignment for the segment so that the kernel may correctly align allocations. Currently the chosen alignment is much lower (8 byte) than the minimum allocation alignment 4096 bytes, but in the future this might change.

feat(thread-local): Better thread-local impl

This change upgrades the thread-local implementation used, the big reason is discovered UB in the way `Option` was used to detect uninitialized fields (the layout of `Option<T>` is actually *not* required to produce `Option::<T>::None` when "transmuting" from an zeroed byte slice).

This change also takes the opportunity and adds proper destructor  (ie `Drop`) support to thread local variables.

title: feat(kernel): better frame allocator
body:
This PR implements a more sophisticated frame allocation scheme that - unlike currently - hands out `Frame` metadata structs that can be used to track metadata even while frames are in use.

The high level interface is this:

- `allocate_one() -> Option<NonNull<Frame>>` - Allocate a single frame (only supported alignment is `PAGE_SIZE`). This will attempt to allocate from a hart-local frame cache first before falling back on the globally shared allocator.
- `allocate_contiguous(layout: Layout) -> Option<linked_list::List<Frame>>` - Allocate a number of frames that satisfy the given layouts size and alignment. Both size and alignment must be at least `PAGE_SIZE`. This will attempt to allocate from a hart-local frame cache first before falling back on the globally shared allocator.
- `deallocate_contiguous(linked_list::List<Frame>)` - Deallocate a list of frames. The caller doesn't need to remember the original layout passed to `allocate_contiguous`. Freed frames are currently never returned to the global allocator, instead they will only ever be returned to the hart-local cache.

commit.message:
chore(loader): report TLS template alignment

This change ammends the `TlsTemplate` struct with a field reporting the chosen alignment for the segment so that the kernel may correctly align allocations. Currently the chosen alignment is much lower (8 byte) than the minimum allocation alignment 4096 bytes, but in the future this might change.

feat(thread-local): Better thread-local impl

This change upgrades the thread-local implementation used, the big reason is discovered UB in the way `Option` was used to detect uninitialized fields (the layout of `Option<T>` is actually *not* required to produce `Option::<T>::None` when "transmuting" from an zeroed byte slice).

This change also takes the opportunity and adds proper destructor  (ie `Drop`) support to thread local variables.

feat(kernel): frame allocator

This change implements a proper frame allocator for the kernel, that *unlike* the previous frame allocation schemes primarily deals with `Frame` metadata structs that will be used throughout the higher-level virtual memory management system

title: feat: VM (finally)
body:
This PR brings all the pieces together implementing a proper virtual memory subsystem. Key components of the new system:

- `Frame` is a thread-safe reference counted RAII pointer to a `FrameInfo` struct which represents metadata about a frame of physical memory. `Frame`s are handed out the `frame_allocator` and - just like an `Arc` once all instances of `Frame` are dropped, the underlying `FrameInfo` will be marked as free and returned to the `frame_allocator`.
- `FrameList` is a mutable always sorted list of `Frame`s.
- `AddressSpace` is the main type of the subsystem, it represents an address space (kernel or user) and allows manipulating it through various methods. An `AddressSpace` is a sorted list of `AddressSpaceRegion`s implemented using a binary search Weak AVL tree.
- `AddressSpaceRegion` is a contiguous region of virtual memory and associated flags backed by a virtual memory object `Vmo`. A single `Vmo` can be mapped into virtual memory by many `AddressSpaceRegions`.
- Virtual memory objects come in two flavors currently: `WiredVmo` and `PagedVmo`
- `WiredVmo` represents *wired* physical memory and therefore cannot be resized, decomitted, etc. `WiredVmo` is only used for kernel mappings and a very few select user space mappings (such as the WASM VMContext).
- `PagedVmo` is the more complex and sophisticated variant, it represents physical memory that is backed by a pager and which can be paged in and out of memory as necessary. (pagers are not yet implemented but will enable things like disk swap). They also serve as the basis for copy-on-write memory. Internally they use a `FrameList` to determine which frames are resident in memory and which are aliased to one another.
- `ZERO_FRAME` is a global `PagedVmo` that gets allocated at startup and is used whenever zero initialized memory is requested. In the absence of pager backed VMOs the only way to create a Vmo is by cloning it.

commit.message:
feat(kernel/frame_alloc): implement `mmu::FrameAllocator`

This change adds the initial work to make the new `FrameAllocator` compatible with the interface required by the `mmu` crate

fix(wavltree): take root in `clear`

This fixes a bug where a `WAVLTree` would be left in an invalid state after calling `clear`: It's elements would have been dropped while the struct retain pointers to them causing a use after free
fix(kernel/riscv64): correctly save & restore all registers
feat(kernel): hook up kernel aspace to riscv64 trap handler

title: feat: implement `AddressSpace:: map_specific`
body: This implements `AddressSpace:: map_specific` which can be used to map a `Vmo` at a specific virtual address instead of the potentially randomly chosen location of `AddressSpace::map`.

title: chore: optional `AddressSpaceRegion` name
body: This change makes the `AddressSpaceRegion` name optional, as it is used for debugging anyway and regions might not actually have any associated name.

title: feat: implement `AddressSpace::unmap`
body:
Implements the `AddressSpace::unmap(range: Range<VirtualAddress>)` method which can be used to unmap previously established mappings in the address space.

I'm not super happy with the current solution, as it silently ignores attempts to unmap already unmapped regions, but it will suffice as a first version.

title: fix(mmu): enforce and document invariants
body: This PR more strictly enforces invariants of the `AddressSpace` methods. It also documents these invariants and marks some methods as `unsafe` as appropriate.

commit.message:
fix(mmu): enforce and document invariants

This change more strictly enforces invariants of the `AddressSpace` methods. It also documents these invariants and marks some methods as `unsafe` as appropriate.
fix(loader): declare and document unsafe usages

title: fix(kernel): stricter `AddressSpace` methods
body: This PR makes the methods of the `AddressSpace` more strict, enforcing more invariants, enforcing them upfront *before* any mutation happens and documenting them more clearly. This is incredibly important as the address space methods operate on potentially untrusted userspace inputs (values parsed from WASM or derived from values parsed from WASM) which probably have undergone validation and checks before arriving here, but its still good to make sure. These methods are incredibly central to the OS security

commit.message: wip: zero out userspace half of kernel aspace
fix(kernel/vm): ignore already unmapped pages in `ArchAddressSpace::unmap`
fix(kernel/vm): remove `remap` method and make `map` less strict

title: refactor(loader): replace usage of `mmu`
body:
This PR begins the process of removing the `mmu` crate. It has served us well, but as the virtual memory subsystem in the kernel begins to mature, the `loader` and `kernel` requirements for hardware memory management are diverging.

This PR then starts and removed the `mmu` crate as a dependency of the `loader`. This introduces some code duplication, but this appears more sensible to me.

title: feat(kernel): kernel metrics
body:
This PR introduces the facilities around kernel counters, as the next debugging primitive after logging. Kernel counters are per-hart, `u64` counters that can be used to track events across the kernel. 

This PR only introduces the ability to declare counters, followup work should make use of them across the kernel (specifically the vm subsystem) and even later followup work should implement the ability to read out counters via some shell.

title: feat(kernel): `Mmap`
body:
This PR implements a basic version of `MmapSlice` which essentially is a handle to an `AddressSpaceRegion` for use in other parts of the kernel. Just like the vm subsystem it currently doesn't support partial mutation but importantly it doesn't automatically unmap its region on drop, so it is not a complete RAII wrapper.

It is expected that the `InstanceAllocator` will take care of managing the lifecycle. For this reason `MmapSlice` doesn't expose a real constructor, instead `InstanceAllocator` should allocate the `AddressSpaceRegion` in the `AddressSpace` and then construct a `MmapSlice` using `MmapSlice::from_raw`.

title: feat: user address space functionality
body:
The basic features of userspace `AddressSpaces` have been present for a while now, but while integrating the WASM runtime I discovered that actually the APIs aren't quite there yet to support the necessary features.

The implementation of usercopy primitives was a big step and this PR continues this by evolving the `MmapSlice` struct.

commit.message: remove `copy_from_user` & `copy_to_user` in favor of the more universal `with_user_memory_access`
fix: clear sum when entering trap handler
fix riscv register field setting and clearing
feat: exit `array_to_wasm_trampoline` with trap instead of return
refactor: move allocator and addressspace into store

title: fix(kernel/vm): correctly map all pages in `Batch::flush`

commit.message: fix(kernel/vm): correctly map all pages in `Batch::flush`
feat: use fiber for async stack switching

title: chore(deps): update rust crate wasmtime-slab to v29 - autoclosed
body:
This PR contains the following updates:

| Package | Type | Update | Change |
|---|---|---|---|
| [wasmtime-slab](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime) | workspace.dependencies | major | `28.0.1` -> `29.0.0` |

---

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>bytecodealliance/wasmtime (wasmtime-slab)</summary>

### [`v29.0.1`](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/releases/tag/v29.0.1)

[Compare Source](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/compare/v29.0.0...v29.0.1)

#### 29.0.1

Released 2025-01-21.

##### Fixed

-   Fix a missing increment in WASIp1-to-WASIp2 adapter which affected WASI
    configurations that have multiple preopened directories.
    [#​10064](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10064)

### [`v29.0.0`](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/releases/tag/v29.0.0)

[Compare Source](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/compare/v28.0.1...v29.0.0)

#### 29.0.0

Released 2025-01-20.

##### Added

-   Winch now supports epoch-based interruption.
    [#​9737](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9737)

-   Pulley, Wasmtime's WebAssembly interpreter, has seen quite a lot of progress
    and support fleshed out. It's still not 100% complete but should be about
    ready to start kicking the tires.
    [#​9744](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9744)

-   The Wasmtime CLI now supports a `-Wextended-const` flag to control whether the
    `extended-const` wasm proposal is enabled or not.
    [#​9768](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9768)

-   Work continues to progress on the AArch64 Winch backend, bringing it closer to
    completion.
    [#​9762](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9762)
    [#​9767](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9767)
    [#​9751](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9751)
    [#​9784](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9784)
    [#​9781](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9781)
    [#​9792](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9792)
    [#​9787](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9787)
    [#​9798](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9798)
    [#​9850](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9850)

-   Wasmtime now supports a "custom code publisher" which can be useful when
    Wasmtime doesn't have built-in support for a particular environment.
    [#​9778](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9778)

-   Configuration options have been added for `wasmtime-wasi-http` outgoing
    bodies.
    [#​9800](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9800)

-   Log prefixes can now be disabled for the `wasmtime serve` command.
    [#​9821](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9821)

-   A new `WASMTIME_LOG_NO_CONTEXT` environment variable was added to live
    alongside `WASMTIME_LOG`.
    [#​9902](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9902)

-   Release artifacts for aarch64-musl targets are now available.
    [#​9934](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9934)

##### Changed

-   Wasmtime libcalls now return whether a trap happened rather than raising a
    trap directly to better prepare for the Pulley interpreter and an eventual
    implementation of Wasm exception-handling.
    [#​9710](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9710)

-   Wasmtime will now use the Pulley interpreter by default on platforms that
    are not supported by Cranelift.
    [#​9741](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9741)

-   Demangling symbols in profiling and debugging has improved to handle failures
    to demangle C++ symbols.
    [#​9756](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9756)

-   WASI WIT files have been updated to 0.2.3.
    [#​9807](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9807)

-   Wasmtime's `bindgen!` macro in `async` mode no longer uses `#[async_trait]`
    an instead natively uses `async fn` in traits.
    [#​9867](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9867)

-   Floats are no longer canonicalized flowing into or out of components.
    [#​9879](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9879)

-   Instance methods are now translated to static methods in DWARF translation.
    [#​9898](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9898)

-   The C API now supports debug builtins for debugging guest code.
    [#​9915](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9915)

##### Fixed

-   The header file for `wasmtime_instance_pre_instantiate` in the C API has been
    fixed.
    [#​9770](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9770)

-   WebAssembly DWARF is more conservative in its GC pass during translation to
    native DWARF.
    [#​9829](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9829)

-   Debugging intrinsics are fixed on Linux to be exported now.
    [#​9866](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9866)

</details>

title: feat: task executor
body:
This PR implements the basic task executor runtime that will be used to execute cooperatively scheduled tasks (both kernelspace tasks and userspace WASM programs) across all harts.

This is based on the `MultiThreadedAlt` scheduler implemented by `tokio`.

commit.message: fix: use same layout in `JoinHandle` future
fix: spin wait instead of panic when global queue is being pulled from
fix(kernel/executor): correctly shutdown all tasks in `OwnedTasks`

title: feat: bring back multicore support
body: With work on the executor currently ongoing it has become clear that multicore support needs to be brought back. To this end this PR reverts a few changes to loader, namely the loader is now responsible for starting up harts and allocating stacks and TLS regions. This means that the kernel initialization can remain simple while still supporting many cores at the same time.

commit.message: fix(loader): don't zero out BSS from secondary harts
feat(loader): map kernel stacks & TLS regions
fix(kernel): use global shared logger for prettier printing

title: chore(deps): update rust crate rand to v0.9.0
body:
This PR contains the following updates:

| Package | Type | Update | Change |
|---|---|---|---|
| [rand](https://rust-random.github.io/book) ([source](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand)) | dev-dependencies | patch | `0.9.0-beta.3` -> `0.9.0` |

---

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>rust-random/rand (rand)</summary>

### [`v0.9.0`](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/blob/HEAD/CHANGELOG.md#090---2025-01-27)

[Compare Source](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/compare/0.9.0-beta.3...0.9.0)

##### Security and unsafe

-   Policy: "rand is not a crypto library" ([#​1514](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1514))
-   Remove fork-protection from `ReseedingRng` and `ThreadRng`. Instead, it is recommended to call `ThreadRng::reseed` on fork. ([#​1379](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1379))
-   Use `zerocopy` to replace some `unsafe` code ([#​1349](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1349), [#​1393](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1393), [#​1446](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1446), [#​1502](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1502))

##### Dependencies

-   Bump the MSRV to 1.63.0 ([#​1207](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1207), [#​1246](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1246), [#​1269](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1269), [#​1341](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1341), [#​1416](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1416), [#​1536](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1536)); note that 1.60.0 may work for dependents when using `--ignore-rust-version`
-   Update to `rand_core` v0.9.0 ([#​1558](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1558))

##### Features

-   Support `std` feature without `getrandom` or `rand_chacha` ([#​1354](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1354))
-   Enable feature `small_rng` by default ([#​1455](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1455))
-   Remove implicit feature `rand_chacha`; use `std_rng` instead. ([#​1473](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1473))
-   Rename feature `serde1` to `serde` ([#​1477](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1477))
-   Rename feature `getrandom` to `os_rng` ([#​1537](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1537))
-   Add feature `thread_rng` ([#​1547](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1547))

##### API changes: rand_core traits

-   Add fn `RngCore::read_adapter` implementing `std::io::Read` ([#​1267](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1267))
-   Add trait `CryptoBlockRng: BlockRngCore`; make `trait CryptoRng: RngCore` ([#​1273](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1273))
-   Add traits `TryRngCore`, `TryCryptoRng` ([#​1424](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1424), [#​1499](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1499))
-   Rename `fn SeedableRng::from_rng` -> `try_from_rng` and add infallible variant `fn from_rng` ([#​1424](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1424))
-   Rename `fn SeedableRng::from_entropy` -> `from_os_rng` and add fallible variant `fn try_from_os_rng` ([#​1424](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1424))
-   Add bounds `Clone` and `AsRef` to associated type `SeedableRng::Seed` ([#​1491](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1491))

##### API changes: Rng trait and top-level fns

-   Rename fn `rand::thread_rng()` to `rand::rng()` and remove from the prelude ([#​1506](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1506))
-   Remove fn `rand::random()` from the prelude ([#​1506](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1506))
-   Add top-level fns `random_iter`, `random_range`, `random_bool`, `random_ratio`, `fill` ([#​1488](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1488))
-   Re-introduce fn `Rng::gen_iter` as `random_iter` ([#​1305](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1305), [#​1500](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1500))
-   Rename fn `Rng::gen` to `random` to avoid conflict with the new `gen` keyword in Rust 2024 ([#​1438](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1438))
-   Rename fns `Rng::gen_range` to `random_range`, `gen_bool` to `random_bool`, `gen_ratio` to `random_ratio` ([#​1505](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1505))
-   Annotate panicking methods with `#[track_caller]` ([#​1442](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1442), [#​1447](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1447))

##### API changes: RNGs

-   Fix `<SmallRng as SeedableRng>::Seed` size to 256 bits ([#​1455](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1455))
-   Remove first parameter (`rng`) of `ReseedingRng::new` ([#​1533](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1533))

##### API changes: Sequences

-   Split trait `SliceRandom` into `IndexedRandom`, `IndexedMutRandom`, `SliceRandom` ([#​1382](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1382))
-   Add `IndexedRandom::choose_multiple_array`, `index::sample_array` ([#​1453](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1453), [#​1469](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1469))

##### API changes: Distributions: renames

-   Rename module `rand::distributions` to `rand::distr` ([#​1470](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1470))
-   Rename distribution `Standard` to `StandardUniform` ([#​1526](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1526))
-   Move `distr::Slice` -> `distr::slice::Choose`, `distr::EmptySlice` -> `distr::slice::Empty` ([#​1548](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1548))
-   Rename trait `distr::DistString` -> `distr::SampleString` ([#​1548](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1548))
-   Rename `distr::DistIter` -> `distr::Iter`, `distr::DistMap` -> `distr::Map` ([#​1548](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1548))

##### API changes: Distributions

-   Relax `Sized` bound on `Distribution<T> for &D` ([#​1278](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1278))
-   Remove impl of `Distribution<Option<T>>` for `StandardUniform` ([#​1526](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1526))
-   Let distribution `StandardUniform` support all `NonZero*` types ([#​1332](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1332))
-   Fns `{Uniform, UniformSampler}::{new, new_inclusive}` return a `Result` (instead of potentially panicking) ([#​1229](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1229))
-   Distribution `Uniform` implements `TryFrom` instead of `From` for ranges ([#​1229](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1229))
-   Add `UniformUsize` ([#​1487](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1487))
-   Remove support for generating `isize` and `usize` values with `StandardUniform`, `Uniform` (except via `UniformUsize`) and `Fill` and usage as a `WeightedAliasIndex` weight ([#​1487](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1487))
-   Add impl `DistString` for distributions `Slice<char>` and `Uniform<char>` ([#​1315](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1315))
-   Add fn `Slice::num_choices` ([#​1402](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1402))
-   Add fn `p()` for distribution `Bernoulli` to access probability ([#​1481](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1481))

##### API changes: Weighted distributions

-   Add `pub` module `rand::distr::weighted`, moving `WeightedIndex` there ([#​1548](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1548))
-   Add trait `weighted::Weight`, allowing `WeightedIndex` to trap overflow ([#​1353](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1353))
-   Add fns `weight, weights, total_weight` to distribution `WeightedIndex` ([#​1420](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1420))
-   Rename enum `WeightedError` to `weighted::Error`, revising variants ([#​1382](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1382)) and mark as `#[non_exhaustive]` ([#​1480](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1480))

##### API changes: SIMD

-   Switch to `std::simd`, expand SIMD & docs ([#​1239](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1239))

##### Reproducibility-breaking changes

-   Make `ReseedingRng::reseed` discard remaining data from the last block generated ([#​1379](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1379))
-   Change fn `SmallRng::seed_from_u64` implementation ([#​1203](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1203))
-   Allow `UniformFloat::new` samples and `UniformFloat::sample_single` to yield `high` ([#​1462](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1462))
-   Fix portability of distribution `Slice` ([#​1469](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1469))
-   Make `Uniform` for `usize` portable via `UniformUsize` ([#​1487](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1487))
-   Fix `IndexdRandom::choose_multiple_weighted` for very small seeds and optimize for large input length / low memory ([#​1530](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1530))

##### Reproducibility-breaking optimisations

-   Optimize fn `sample_floyd`, affecting output of `rand::seq::index::sample` and `rand::seq::SliceRandom::choose_multiple` ([#​1277](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1277))
-   New, faster algorithms for `IteratorRandom::choose` and `choose_stable` ([#​1268](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1268))
-   New, faster algorithms for `SliceRandom::shuffle` and `partial_shuffle` ([#​1272](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1272))
-   Optimize distribution `Uniform`: use Canon's method (single sampling) / Lemire's method (distribution sampling) for faster sampling (breaks value stability; [#​1287](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1287))
-   Optimize fn `sample_single_inclusive` for floats (+~20% perf) ([#​1289](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1289))

##### Other optimisations

-   Improve `SmallRng` initialization performance ([#​1482](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1482))
-   Optimise SIMD widening multiply ([#​1247](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1247))

##### Other

-   Add `Cargo.lock.msrv` file ([#​1275](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1275))
-   Reformat with `rustfmt` and enforce ([#​1448](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1448))

commit.message: chore(deps): update rust crate rand to v0.9.0

title: chore(deps): update rust crate rand to 0.9.0
body:
This PR contains the following updates:

| Package | Type | Update | Change |
|---|---|---|---|
| [rand](https://rust-random.github.io/book) ([source](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand)) | workspace.dependencies | minor | `0.8.5` -> `0.9.0` |

---

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>rust-random/rand (rand)</summary>

### [`v0.9.0`](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/blob/HEAD/CHANGELOG.md#090---2025-01-27)

[Compare Source](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/compare/0.8.5...0.9.0)

##### Security and unsafe

-   Policy: "rand is not a crypto library" ([#​1514](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1514))
-   Remove fork-protection from `ReseedingRng` and `ThreadRng`. Instead, it is recommended to call `ThreadRng::reseed` on fork. ([#​1379](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1379))
-   Use `zerocopy` to replace some `unsafe` code ([#​1349](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1349), [#​1393](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1393), [#​1446](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1446), [#​1502](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1502))

##### Dependencies

-   Bump the MSRV to 1.63.0 ([#​1207](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1207), [#​1246](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1246), [#​1269](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1269), [#​1341](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1341), [#​1416](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1416), [#​1536](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1536)); note that 1.60.0 may work for dependents when using `--ignore-rust-version`
-   Update to `rand_core` v0.9.0 ([#​1558](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1558))

##### Features

-   Support `std` feature without `getrandom` or `rand_chacha` ([#​1354](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1354))
-   Enable feature `small_rng` by default ([#​1455](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1455))
-   Remove implicit feature `rand_chacha`; use `std_rng` instead. ([#​1473](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1473))
-   Rename feature `serde1` to `serde` ([#​1477](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1477))
-   Rename feature `getrandom` to `os_rng` ([#​1537](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1537))
-   Add feature `thread_rng` ([#​1547](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1547))

##### API changes: rand_core traits

-   Add fn `RngCore::read_adapter` implementing `std::io::Read` ([#​1267](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1267))
-   Add trait `CryptoBlockRng: BlockRngCore`; make `trait CryptoRng: RngCore` ([#​1273](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1273))
-   Add traits `TryRngCore`, `TryCryptoRng` ([#​1424](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1424), [#​1499](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1499))
-   Rename `fn SeedableRng::from_rng` -> `try_from_rng` and add infallible variant `fn from_rng` ([#​1424](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1424))
-   Rename `fn SeedableRng::from_entropy` -> `from_os_rng` and add fallible variant `fn try_from_os_rng` ([#​1424](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1424))
-   Add bounds `Clone` and `AsRef` to associated type `SeedableRng::Seed` ([#​1491](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1491))

##### API changes: Rng trait and top-level fns

-   Rename fn `rand::thread_rng()` to `rand::rng()` and remove from the prelude ([#​1506](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1506))
-   Remove fn `rand::random()` from the prelude ([#​1506](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1506))
-   Add top-level fns `random_iter`, `random_range`, `random_bool`, `random_ratio`, `fill` ([#​1488](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1488))
-   Re-introduce fn `Rng::gen_iter` as `random_iter` ([#​1305](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1305), [#​1500](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1500))
-   Rename fn `Rng::gen` to `random` to avoid conflict with the new `gen` keyword in Rust 2024 ([#​1438](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1438))
-   Rename fns `Rng::gen_range` to `random_range`, `gen_bool` to `random_bool`, `gen_ratio` to `random_ratio` ([#​1505](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1505))
-   Annotate panicking methods with `#[track_caller]` ([#​1442](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1442), [#​1447](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1447))

##### API changes: RNGs

-   Fix `<SmallRng as SeedableRng>::Seed` size to 256 bits ([#​1455](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1455))
-   Remove first parameter (`rng`) of `ReseedingRng::new` ([#​1533](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1533))

##### API changes: Sequences

-   Split trait `SliceRandom` into `IndexedRandom`, `IndexedMutRandom`, `SliceRandom` ([#​1382](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1382))
-   Add `IndexedRandom::choose_multiple_array`, `index::sample_array` ([#​1453](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1453), [#​1469](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1469))

##### API changes: Distributions: renames

-   Rename module `rand::distributions` to `rand::distr` ([#​1470](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1470))
-   Rename distribution `Standard` to `StandardUniform` ([#​1526](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1526))
-   Move `distr::Slice` -> `distr::slice::Choose`, `distr::EmptySlice` -> `distr::slice::Empty` ([#​1548](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1548))
-   Rename trait `distr::DistString` -> `distr::SampleString` ([#​1548](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1548))
-   Rename `distr::DistIter` -> `distr::Iter`, `distr::DistMap` -> `distr::Map` ([#​1548](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1548))

##### API changes: Distributions

-   Relax `Sized` bound on `Distribution<T> for &D` ([#​1278](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1278))
-   Remove impl of `Distribution<Option<T>>` for `StandardUniform` ([#​1526](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1526))
-   Let distribution `StandardUniform` support all `NonZero*` types ([#​1332](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1332))
-   Fns `{Uniform, UniformSampler}::{new, new_inclusive}` return a `Result` (instead of potentially panicking) ([#​1229](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1229))
-   Distribution `Uniform` implements `TryFrom` instead of `From` for ranges ([#​1229](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1229))
-   Add `UniformUsize` ([#​1487](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1487))
-   Remove support for generating `isize` and `usize` values with `StandardUniform`, `Uniform` (except via `UniformUsize`) and `Fill` and usage as a `WeightedAliasIndex` weight ([#​1487](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1487))
-   Add impl `DistString` for distributions `Slice<char>` and `Uniform<char>` ([#​1315](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1315))
-   Add fn `Slice::num_choices` ([#​1402](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1402))
-   Add fn `p()` for distribution `Bernoulli` to access probability ([#​1481](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1481))

##### API changes: Weighted distributions

-   Add `pub` module `rand::distr::weighted`, moving `WeightedIndex` there ([#​1548](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1548))
-   Add trait `weighted::Weight`, allowing `WeightedIndex` to trap overflow ([#​1353](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1353))
-   Add fns `weight, weights, total_weight` to distribution `WeightedIndex` ([#​1420](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1420))
-   Rename enum `WeightedError` to `weighted::Error`, revising variants ([#​1382](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1382)) and mark as `#[non_exhaustive]` ([#​1480](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1480))

##### API changes: SIMD

-   Switch to `std::simd`, expand SIMD & docs ([#​1239](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1239))

##### Reproducibility-breaking changes

-   Make `ReseedingRng::reseed` discard remaining data from the last block generated ([#​1379](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1379))
-   Change fn `SmallRng::seed_from_u64` implementation ([#​1203](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1203))
-   Allow `UniformFloat::new` samples and `UniformFloat::sample_single` to yield `high` ([#​1462](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1462))
-   Fix portability of distribution `Slice` ([#​1469](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1469))
-   Make `Uniform` for `usize` portable via `UniformUsize` ([#​1487](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1487))
-   Fix `IndexdRandom::choose_multiple_weighted` for very small seeds and optimize for large input length / low memory ([#​1530](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1530))

##### Reproducibility-breaking optimisations

-   Optimize fn `sample_floyd`, affecting output of `rand::seq::index::sample` and `rand::seq::SliceRandom::choose_multiple` ([#​1277](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1277))
-   New, faster algorithms for `IteratorRandom::choose` and `choose_stable` ([#​1268](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1268))
-   New, faster algorithms for `SliceRandom::shuffle` and `partial_shuffle` ([#​1272](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1272))
-   Optimize distribution `Uniform`: use Canon's method (single sampling) / Lemire's method (distribution sampling) for faster sampling (breaks value stability; [#​1287](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1287))
-   Optimize fn `sample_single_inclusive` for floats (+~20% perf) ([#​1289](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1289))

##### Other optimisations

-   Improve `SmallRng` initialization performance ([#​1482](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1482))
-   Optimise SIMD widening multiply ([#​1247](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1247))

##### Other

-   Add `Cargo.lock.msrv` file ([#​1275](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1275))
-   Reformat with `rustfmt` and enforce ([#​1448](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1448))
-   Apply Clippy suggestions and enforce ([#​1448](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1448), [#​1474](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1474))
-   Move all benchmarks to new `benches` crate ([#​1329](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1329), [#​1439](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1439)) and migrate to Criterion ([#​1490](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1490))

##### Documentation

-   Improve `ThreadRng` related docs ([#​1257](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1257))
-   Docs: enable experimental `--generate-link-to-definition` feature ([#​1327](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1327))
-   Better doc of crate features, use `doc_auto_cfg` ([#​1411](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1411), [#​1450](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1450))

</details>

---

### Configuration

ðŸš¦ **Automerge**: Disabled by config. Please merge this manually once you are satisfied.

â™» **Rebasing**: Whenever PR becomes conflicted, or you tick the rebase/retry checkbox.

ðŸ”• **Ignore**: Close this PR and you won't be reminded about this update again.

-   Make `ReseedingRng::reseed` discard remaining data from the last block generated ([#​1379](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1379))
-   Change fn `SmallRng::seed_from_u64` implementation ([#​1203](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1203))
-   Allow `UniformFloat::new` samples and `UniformFloat::sample_single` to yield `high` ([#​1462](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1462))
-   Fix portability of distribution `Slice` ([#​1469](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1469))
-   Make `Uniform` for `usize` portable via `UniformUsize` ([#​1487](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1487))
-   Fix `IndexdRandom::choose_multiple_weighted` for very small seeds and optimize for large input length / low memory ([#​1530](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1530))

##### Reproducibility-breaking optimisations

-   Optimize fn `sample_floyd`, affecting output of `rand::seq::index::sample` and `rand::seq::SliceRandom::choose_multiple` ([#​1277](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1277))
-   New, faster algorithms for `IteratorRandom::choose` and `choose_stable` ([#​1268](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1268))
-   New, faster algorithms for `SliceRandom::shuffle` and `partial_shuffle` ([#​1272](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1272))
-   Optimize distribution `Uniform`: use Canon's method (single sampling) / Lemire's method (distribution sampling) for faster sampling (breaks value stability; [#​1287](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1287))
-   Optimize fn `sample_single_inclusive` for floats (+~20% perf) ([#​1289](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1289))

##### Other optimisations

-   Improve `SmallRng` initialization performance ([#​1482](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1482))
-   Optimise SIMD widening multiply ([#​1247](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1247))

##### Other

-   Add `Cargo.lock.msrv` file ([#​1275](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1275))
-   Reformat with `rustfmt` and enforce ([#​1448](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1448))
-   Apply Clippy suggestions and enforce ([#​1448](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1448), [#​1474](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1474))
-   Move all benchmarks to new `benches` crate ([#​1329](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1329), [#​1439](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1439)) and migrate to Criterion ([#​1490](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1490))

##### Documentation

-   Improve `ThreadRng` related docs ([#​1257](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1257))
-   Docs: enable experimental `--generate-link-to-definition` feature ([#​1327](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1327))
-   Better doc of crate features, use `doc_auto_cfg` ([#​1411](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1411), [#​1450](https://redirect.github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1450))

</details>

title: fix: add callback `executor::run` to spawn hart-local tasks
body:
This PR fixes a "bug" where the initial test task for each HART would be scheduled through the global run queue and therefore distributed randomly among the workers. This is usually what we want (therefore "bug" in quotes) but not in this specific case where we want each hart to run their own task.

The long-term proper solution would be to a add CPU affinity to tasks, but this PR adds a callback after the worker was initialized so we can spawn the task then.

title: fefactor: executor
body: Just cleans up the executor code a bit and adds more explanatory comments

title: feat: async timers
body: This PR adds support for async timers to scheduler, users can call `sleep` or `sleep_until` and the task (only works inside tasks) will be suspended until the timer runs out. This is implemented through per-worker timer wheels that multiplex a potentially quite large number of timers. These timer wheels will be used by the workers to determine the next timeout (if any)

title: fix: simplify scheduler & fix timing issues
body:
The existing scheduler that was largely ported from Tokio has a number of deficiencies like deadlocks, crashes, etc. At the same time it also is quite overcomplicated which makes debugging these issues doubly complicated.

This PR implements a much simpler scheduler that also doesn't suffer from a lot of the deadlocks mentioned above. It gets rid of the "Core passing" idea from Tokio and instead has a fixed number of workers and their associated metadata.

title: test: add `sync` tests
body: This PR refactors the `sync` crate to be more testable, including `loom` tests.

title: feat: bring back test harness
body: This PR brings back the test harness, but in a simpler form. Tests can (currently) only be declared inside the `kernel` all other crates should as much as possible rely on hosted tests

title: feat: allow filtering of log messages
body:
This PR ports a simplified subset of the `tracing-subscriber` `EnvFilter` logic so that we can finally filter log messages dynamically!

The bootarg is called `log` and can be used with the same syntax as `Envfilter` (just without the support for filtering by message fields).

```sh
just run "" --append "log=trace,cranelift_codegen=off"
```

at long last closes #11

commit.message: feat: allow filtering of log messages

title: fix: don't share the zero frame for write
body: This fixes a stupid bug where THE ZERO FRAME provider would always return the zero frame even for write mappings. This of course isn't great and led to all memory mappings being mapped to the same Frame which obviously meant horrific data corruption.

commit.message:
fix: don't share the zero frame for write

This fixes a stupid bug where THE ZERO FRAME provider would always return the zero frame even for write mappings. This of course isn't great and led to all memory mappings being mapped to the same Frame which obviously meant horrific data corruption.

title: wip: kernel shell
body:
This PR adds a very basic early debugging shell which currently has 4 commands:
- `version` to print out information about various components versions
- `panic` to deliberately cause a kernel panic
- `fault` to deliberately cause a fault (nullptr dereference)
- `shutdown` to shutdown the kernel & machine

title: fix: correctly return from `JoinHandle` when task fails
body: This PR fixes a bug in the `JoinHandle` Future code that would swallow failures from awaited tasks, such as panics and cancellations and always report `Ok(())`

This PR fixes a bug in the `JoinHandle` Future code that would swallow failures from awaited tasks, such as panics and cancellations and always report `Ok(())`

title: chore(deps): update rust crate wasmtime-slab to v30
body:
This PR contains the following updates:

| Package | Type | Update | Change |
|---|---|---|---|
| [wasmtime-slab](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime) | workspace.dependencies | major | `28.0.1` -> `30.0.0` |

---

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>bytecodealliance/wasmtime (wasmtime-slab)</summary>

### [`v30.0.0`](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/releases/tag/v30.0.0)

[Compare Source](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/compare/v29.0.1...v30.0.0)

#### 30.0.0

Released 2025-02-20.

##### Added

-   New `wasmtime-wasi-io` crate provides a `#![no_std]` wasi:io implementation,
    factored out of `wasmtime-wasi`. Users of `wasmtime-wasi` don't have to
    depend on this new crate.
    [#​10036](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10036)

-   Wasmtime's interpreter, Pulley, is now complete and has been listed as
    [tier 2].
    [#​9897](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9897)
    [#​9884](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9884)
    [#​9943](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9943)
    [#​9944](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9944)
    [#​9983](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9983)
    [#​9966](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9966)
    [#​9935](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9935)
    [#​10034](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10034)
    [#​10057](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10057)
    [#​10095](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10095)

-   Wasmtime's CI now checks that the repository builds for `aarch64-apple-ios`.
    Note that no tests are run for this target, so it's still [tier 3].
    [#​9888](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9888)

-   Winch's support for AArch64 and simd on x64 have continued to progress
    well. Winch additionally now fully supports the `threads` WebAssembly
    proposal.
    [#​9889](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9889)
    [#​9970](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9970)
    [#​9950](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9950)
    [#​9987](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9987)
    [#​9990](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9990)
    [#​9959](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9959)
    [#​10008](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10008)
    [#​10028](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10028)
    [#​10029](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10029)
    [#​10023](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10023)
    [#​10042](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10042)
    [#​10050](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10050)
    [#​10039](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10039)
    [#​10082](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10082)
    [#​10092](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10092)
    [#​10109](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10109)
    [#​10148](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10148)
    [#​10147](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10147)

-   The `memory64` WebAssembly feature is now enabled by default. This WebAssembly
    proposal is now considered a [tier 1] feature.
    [#​9937](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9937)
    [#​10159](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10159)

-   Wasmtime's full test suite and CI now includes 32-bit platforms such as x86
    and armv7 Linux. These platforms have been added to [tier 3] status and use
    Pulley as their execution backend.
    [#​10025](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10025)

-   Initial experimental support for WASIp3 and async features of the Component
    Model have started to land. These features are not yet ready for
    general-purpose use.
    [#​10044](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10044)
    [#​10047](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10047)
    [#​10083](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10083)
    [#​10103](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10103)

-   The `wasmtime` CLI now supports using a TOML configuration file via `--config`
    in addition to CLI options.
    [#​9811](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9811)
    [#​10132](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10132)

-   Initial support for a new assembler on x64 has been added.
    [#​10110](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10110)
    [#​10178](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10178)

##### Changed

-   `wasmtime-wasi` split the `WasiView` trait into `IoView` and `WasiView`, and
    `wasmtime-wasi-http` re-uses `IoView` in `WasiHttpView`. Details on porting
    for embedders in PR.
    [#​10016](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10016)

-   `wasmtime-wasi` renamed some exported types and traits. Embedders which use
    `Pollable`, `InputStream`, `OutputStream`, `Subscribe`, `HostInputStream`,
    `HostOutputStream`, `PollableFuture`, or `ClosureFuture` from that crate
    will need to rename those imports to their new names, describe in PR.
    [#​10036](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10036)

-   Components using a 64-bit linear memory should never have worked before, but
    they're now rejected earlier in the validation process.
    [#​9952](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9952)

-   Module validation is now deterministic in the face of multiple errors.
    [#​9947](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9947)

-   Wasmtime's minimum supported version of Rust is now 1.82.0.
    [#​9956](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9956)

-   Cranelift will now deduplicate `trap[n]z` instructions.
    [#​10004](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10004)

-   The `--emit-clif` option to `wasmtime compile` now emits post-optimization
    CLIF.
    [#​10011](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10011)

-   The `signals-based-traps` Cargo feature has been removed in favor of
    auto-detection of available features based on the `#[cfg]` directives
    available for the target platform.
    [#​9941](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9941)

-   The `async_stack_zeroing` configuration knob now covers all stack allocations,
    not just those from the pooling allocator.
    [#​10027](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10027)

-   Wasmtime should work-by-default on more platforms, even those where Cranelift
    has no support for the architecture. This is done by ensuring some
    architecture and platform-specific bits are removed on unknown platforms (and
    Pulley is used instead).
    [#​10107](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10107)

-   Wasmtime now compiles on platforms missing 64-bit atomics.
    [#​10134](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10134)

[tier 1]: https://docs.wasmtime.dev/stability-tiers.html#tier-1

[tier 2]: https://docs.wasmtime.dev/stability-tiers.html#tier-2

[tier 3]: https://docs.wasmtime.dev/stability-tiers.html#tier-3

##### Fixed

-   Fixed a missing case for `Ref::matches_ty` should return `true`.
    [#​9985](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9985)

-   A bug with using the `single_pass` register allocation algorithm on x64/s390x
    has been fixed by refactoring how branches are represented.
    [#​10086](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10086)
    [#​10087](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10087)

-   A bug with argument extensions on riscv64 has been fixed.
    [#​10069](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10069)

-   The `PartialEq` implementation for `RegisteredType` has been fixed.
    [#​10091](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10091)

-   The output of `component::bindgen!` now works with `#![no_std]` crates.
    [#​10105](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10105)

-   Fix `wasmtime wast` when combined with `--fuel`.
    [#​10121](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10121)

-   The `wat` feature of the C API is now plumbed correctly in a few more
    locations.
    [#​10124](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10124)

-   Spurious wake-ups in `blocking_*` methods of `InputStream` and `OutputStream`
    have been fixed.
    [#​10113](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10113)

### [`v29.0.1`](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/releases/tag/v29.0.1)

[Compare Source](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/compare/v29.0.0...v29.0.1)

#### 29.0.1

Released 2025-01-21.

##### Fixed

-   Fix a missing increment in WASIp1-to-WASIp2 adapter which affected WASI
    configurations that have multiple preopened directories.
    [#​10064](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10064)

### [`v29.0.0`](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/releases/tag/v29.0.0)

[Compare Source](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/compare/v28.0.1...v29.0.0)

#### 29.0.0

Released 2025-01-20.

##### Added

-   Winch now supports epoch-based interruption.
    [#​9737](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9737)

-   Pulley, Wasmtime's WebAssembly interpreter, has seen quite a lot of progress
    and support fleshed out. It's still not 100% complete but should be about
    ready to start kicking the tires.
    [#​9744](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9744)

-   The Wasmtime CLI now supports a `-Wextended-const` flag to control whether the
    `extended-const` wasm proposal is enabled or not.
    [#​9768](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9768)

-   Work continues to progress on the AArch64 Winch backend, bringing it closer to
    completion.
    [#​9762](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9762)
    [#​9767](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9767)
    [#​9751](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9751)
    [#​9784](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9784)
    [#​9781](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9781)
    [#​9792](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9792)
    [#​9787](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9787)
    [#​9798](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9798)
    [#​9850](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9850)

-   Wasmtime now supports a "custom code publisher" which can be useful when
    Wasmtime doesn't have built-in support for a particular environment.
    [#​9778](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9778)

-   Configuration options have been added for `wasmtime-wasi-http` outgoing
    bodies.
    [#​9800](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9800)

-   Log prefixes can now be disabled for the `wasmtime serve` command.
    [#​9821](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9821)

-   A new `WASMTIME_LOG_NO_CONTEXT` environment variable was added to live
    alongside `WASMTIME_LOG`.
    [#​9902](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9902)

-   Release artifacts for aarch64-musl targets are now available.
    [#​9934](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9934)

##### Changed

-   Wasmtime libcalls now return whether a trap happened rather than raising a
    trap directly to better prepare for the Pulley interpreter and an eventual
    implementation of Wasm exception-handling.
    [#​9710](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9710)

-   Wasmtime will now use the Pulley interpreter by default on platforms that
    are not supported by Cranelift.
    [#​9741](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9741)

-   Demangling symbols in profiling and debugging has improved to handle failures
    to demangle C++ symbols.
    [#​9756](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9756)

-   WASI WIT files have been updated to 0.2.3.
    [#​9807](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9807)

-   Wasmtime's `bindgen!` macro in `async` mode no longer uses `#[async_trait]`
    an instead natively uses `async fn` in traits.
    [#​9867](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9867)

-   Floats are no longer canonicalized flowing into or out of components.
    [#​9879](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9879)

-   Instance methods are now translated to static methods in DWARF translation.
    [#​9898](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9898)

-   The C API now supports debug builtins for debugging guest code.
    [#​9915](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9915)

##### Fixed

-   The header file for `wasmtime_instance_pre_instantiate` in the C API has been
    fixed.
    [#​9770](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9770)

-   WebAssembly DWARF is more conservative in its GC pass during translation to
    native DWARF.
    [#​9829](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9829)

-   Debugging intrinsics are fixed on Linux to be exported now.
    [#​9866](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9866)

</details>

title: fix: make `unwind2` more resilient
body:
This PR makes the stack walking implementation of `unwind2` more resilient and useful outside of panics. The big fix here is that apparently leaf functions **do not** spill their return address to the stack instead keeping it in register and EH_FRAME has no explicit instructions on how to recover that. At least according to LLVMs libunwind
https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/blob/6de5d1e46d1812de2bbbbe8d8d2c811e4d16acbe/libunwind/src/DwarfInstructions.hpp#L295-L296
Kind of annoyed that this was so obscure and difficult to find :/

In the way we previously used stack walking this was fine since `save_context` always explicitly pushed the return address onto the stack:

https://github.com/JonasKruckenberg/k23/blob/4c7edf0e05bae5f979c947224c470d66a120ac8d/libs/unwind2/src/arch/riscv64.rs#L216-L219

In essence when called through `begin_unwind` there never was a leaf function that would show this behavior.

But now with this fixed we can finally construct stack traces from inside the kernels teap handler too! (In the trap handler we don't control where the return address lives, so need to deal with it potentially not being on stack at all).

commit.message:
fix: allow `unwind2` to be used in more situations.

This change fixes the stack walking code which previously overly relied on the particular construction of `with_context`. It is now more correct and more versatile allowing consumers to constructs stack traces from arbitrary register+pc contexts.

title: fix(backtrace): remove broken support for short backtraces
body: This change removed the already broken support for short backtraces since it would sometimes cause the entire backtrace to not print at all.

commit.message:

This change removed the already broken support for short backtraces since it would sometimes cause the entire backtrace to not print at all.

title: feat(backtrace): allow `Backtrace` to be constructed from raw register context
body: This change implements `Backtrace::from_registers` which builds on the support in `unwind2` to walk the stack beginning with an arbitrary register context. This will allow us to print backtraces in the kernel trap handler (where we want to print a backtrace of a different stack)

title: chore(wavltree): release v0.0.7
body:
## ðŸ¤– New release * `wavltree`: 0.0.6 -> 0.0.7 (âœ“ API compatible changes)
Changelog

## [0.0.7](https://github.com/JonasKruckenberg/k23/compare/v0.0.6...v0.0.7) - 2025-02-21 ### Added - Rust `2024` edition (#309)

--- This PR was generated with [release-plz](https://github.com/release-plz/release-plz/).

title: fix: panics in trap handler
body: This allows panicking in the trap handler, which while not desired is a good debugging feature to have

title: feat: overhaul trap handling part 1: panic on trap
body:
This PR is the first patch a series of patches to overhaul the trap handling. It completely removes the old `catch_traps` functionality in favor of unwinding the trapped stack similar to a panic (only if the VM page fault handler couldn't correct the trap first of course).
This has two benefits:
- We can print stack traces for traps which tremendously help with debugging.
- We can use the regular `panic` infrastructure for dealing with traps. In particular, this means that `catch_unwind` will also catch unhandled traps AND that traps inside tasks will be handled just like regular panics. This makes the kernel simpler and helps with stability.

title: chore: implement `Debug` for `AddressSpace`
body: as the name suggests

title: fix: user aspace max range
body: This fixes a bug where a user address space could generate invalid non-canonical addresses because the max range was incorrectly configured

commit.message: fix: use correct address space range for user aspace

fix: use correct max address space ranges

This fixes a bug where a user address space could generate invalid non-canonical addresses because the max range was incorrectly configured

title: feat: overhaul trap handling part 2: page handling
body: This overhauls the page fault handling part of the trap handling system. Each `Task` is now associated with an `AddressSpace` and holds a pointer to that address space.

commit.message:
feat: overhaul trap handling part 2: page handling

This overhauls the page fault handling part of the trap handling system. Each `Task` is now associated with an `AddressSpace` and holds a pointer to that address space.

title: fix: dont panic in `Scheduler::current_task`
body: Fixes a panic in `Scheduler::current_task` when the function gets called outside of the worker loop.

commit.message:
fix: allow unwinding past trap handler

This changes the trap handler ABI from `C` to `C-unwind` to allow the unwinder to unwind past it

title: feat: correctly initialize InstanceAllocator
body: Instead of the previous default implementation, this correctly initializes the instance allocator from an ASID allocator and root RNG maintained by the engine.

title: refactor: use `UserMmap` throughout wasm code
body: This PR makes the WASM `Memory` and `OwnedVMContext` actually use the `UserMmap`

title: chore: misc cleanup
body: some miscellaneous cleanup in the kernel

title: chore: always leave `SUM` bit enabled
body: This change makes it so the RISCV `SUM` (Supervisor User Memory access) bit is set at startup and never unset. This will allow the more complex interwoven memory usage of WASM engines (i.e. allowing access to the shared stack memory and VMContext object)

commit.message:
chore: always leave `SUM` bit enabled.

This change makes it so the RISCV `SUM` (Supervisor User Memory access) bit is set at startup and never unset. This will allow the more complex interwoven memory usage of WASM engines

title: refactor: turn frame allocation functions into `FrameAllocator` methods
body: In preparation for state unification, this PR turns all previously freestanding frame allocation functions `frame_alloc::*` into methods of the `FrameAllocator` struct.

title: chore: instrument vmctx init functions
body: This adds `tracing::instrument` statements to all vmctx init functions since these are critical we'll need as much insight as possible.

title: fix: eagerly commit `OwnedVMContext`
body: Eagerly commit all pages of an `OwnedVMContext` upon creation (we should even pin them in the future) since we need that memory immediately for initialization.

body: This PR makes sure we're in the right address space when beginning to initialize the instance

commit.message: chore(deps): update rust crate syn to v2.0.99

title: chore: make `Store` `Send` & `Sync`
body: This adds the necessary `Send` & `Sync` impls to the VM structs so that `Store` becomes `Send + Sync` and can be used in futures.

title: fix: don't panic on `InstanceAllocator` drop
body: This removes the `Drop` assertion from the placeholder instance allocator. I assumed originally that the instance allocator should be the last place to drop its address space reference, but when running inside the scheduler, the last reference is actually the one kept by the task struct.

title: fix: switch to correct address space in scheduler
body: Since each task *might* have a different address space, we must switch to the correct one before actually executing any code that accesses non-global memory. This PR makes the scheduler switch before polling (not that this is likely not the final way forward for this, instead this should happen *inside* the future being polled, but that's a future todo)

commit.message: fix: switch to correct address space in scheduler

title: wip: allow usermode programs to access kernel stacks
body: This temporary PR allows user mode WASM to run on the kernel stack as well

commit.message: wip: allow usermode programs to access kernel stacks

title: feat: catch WASM traps
body: This PR completes the trap handling overhaul (for now) by adding the ability to catch WASM traps. Note that this is probably the worst code ever written, and *very* placeholder but it gets the job done for now.
