commit.message: fix(deps): update rust crate pin-project to v1.1.10

title: refactor: rename `sync` to `spin`
body: This renames the `sync` crate to `spin` in order to make space for the asynchronous sync primitives.

title: refactor: initial async sync primitives
body: This PR adds initial async primitives in the `sync` submodule. These are quite low level at the moment, but will in the future be used for everything from mutexes to the io reactor

title: fix link to garbage collection issue

comments.body: Hey, thanks for catching that (stupid) mistake of mine! ðŸ˜„

commit.message: fix link to garbage collection issue

title: feat: implement `WaitQueue`
body: This change adds the `WaitQueue` primitive. Essentially a queue of wakers that can be woken one after the other or all at once. This is a very useful building block for almost all async primitives. E.g. will be used to deliver IRQs to subscribed tasks

commit.message:
feat: implement `WaitQueue`

This change adds the `WaitQueue` primitive. Essentially a queue of wakers that can be woken one after the other or all at once.
This is a very useful building block for almost all async primitives. E.g. will be used to deliver IRQs to subscribed tasks

title: feat UART demo
body: This adds a small (kernel space) async task that echoes keyboard input through the interrupt chain.

commit.message: fix: correctly enable interrupts in PLIC

title: fix: correctly enable interrupts in PLIC
body: This fixes a bug in the RISCV PLIC code that would incorrectly do the opposite when trying to enable interrupts.

commit.message: fix: correctly enable interrupts in PLIC

title: feat: await irqs
body:
This PR adds the ability to asynchronously awaiting (external) interrupts with a specific number. The API is very much WIP, but currently looks like this
```rust
let irq_num = 10; // E.g. the UART IRQ number on RISCV

// The line below will suspend the calling task until an interrupt with the IRQ number 10 arrives.
let res = irq::next_event(irq_num).await;
``` 

Note that any number of tasks may await an interrupt.

commit.message: fix: correctly enable interrupts in PLIC

title: chore: move iterator utilities into `util`
body: This PR moves the `Either` and `ZipEq` iterator utilities into the `util` module.

title: feat: `TypedFunc`
body:
This PR implements the `TypedFunc` type and related machinery. `TypedFunc` allows us to front-load the type checking of WASM functions and then on subsequent calls benefit from Rusts compile-time checks again. `TypedFunc` can also optimize its argument and result lowering/lifting.

`TypedFunc` should be the primary means of interacting with WASM functions.

title: chore: call `typos` as part of `just preflight`
body: `typos` is already part of the CI checks for each PR, seeing that the idea behind `just preflight` is to replicate the CI checks locally, we should also run `typos`.

commit.message:
chore: call `typos` as part of `just preflight`

`typos` is already part of the CI checks for each PR, seeing that the idea behind `just preflight` is to replicate the CI checks locally, we should also run `typos`.

title: chore: move WASM array-call code to arch module
body: This change moves the details of calling the array-call trampoline to the `arch` module, since jumping to user mode is very architecture specific.

commit.message:
chore: move WASM array-call code to arch module

This change moves the details of calling the array-call trampoline to the `arch` module, since jumping to user mode is very architecture specific.

title: chore: shell banner & cleanup
body: This cleans up the shell output a bit, as well as adding a (somewhat) nice banner

title: refactor: cleanup func module
body: This cleans up the `wasm::func` module and adds explanatory comments

title: feat: allow configurable short backtrace
body:
This PR adds configurable support for shorter backtraces. Shorter backtraces only print symbols between the `__rust_begin_short_backtrace` and `__rust_end_short_backtrace` frames cutting out the quite verbose frames related to unwinding and backtracing itself.

This behavior can be configured through a boot argument like so `backtrace=short` for short (the new default) backtraces and `backtrace=full` for more verbose full backtraces.

Use with QEMU like so `just run "" --append "backtrace=full"`

title: docs: boot args
body: This adds a few notes on boot arguments.

title: fix: bootargs separator
body: The previous bootargs separator `,` conflicted with the separator for log arguments which isn't great. This PR changes the bootargs separator to `;`.

title: chore: include the aspace region name in page fault info
body: This adds the address space region name to the fault info logging

commit.message: chore: include the aspace region name in page fault info

title: fix: use non-contiguous allocations wherever possible
body: This change brings back non-contiguous physical allocations in places where it makes sense to have them. This helps to make better use of memory especially as we approach the maxmimum system memory.

commit.message:
fix: use non-contiguous allocations wherever possible

This change brings back non-contiguous physical allocations in places where it makes sense to have them. This helps to make better use of memory especially as we approach the maxmimum system memory.

title: chore(deps): update rust crate wasmtime-slab to v31
body:
This PR contains the following updates:

| Package | Type | Update | Change |
|---|---|---|---|
| [wasmtime-slab](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime) | workspace.dependencies | major | `30.0.0` -> `31.0.0` |

---

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>bytecodealliance/wasmtime (wasmtime-slab)</summary>

### [`v31.0.0`](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/releases/tag/v31.0.0)

[Compare Source](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/compare/v30.0.2...v31.0.0)

#### 31.0.0

Released 2025-03-20.

##### Added

-   Winch's implementation of the SIMD proposal for WebAssembly is now
    feature-complete (but still being fuzzed).
    [#​10180](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10180)
    [#​10170](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10170)
    [#​10203](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10203)
    [#​10202](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10202)
    [#​10210](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10210)
    [#​10213](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10213)
    [#​10224](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10224)
    [#​10205](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10205)
    [#​10226](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10226)
    [#​10228](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10228)
    [#​10236](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10236)
    [#​10241](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10241)
    [#​10243](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10243)
    [#​10247](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10247)
    [#​10271](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10271)
    [#​10284](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10284)
    [#​10288](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10288)
    [#​10296](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10296)

-   The pytorch implementation in wasmtime-wasi-nn now has GPU support.
    [#​10204](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10204)

-   Cranelift now supports emitting the AArch64 `extr` instruction.
    [#​10229](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10229)

-   Cranelift now supports emitting the x64 `shld` instruction.
    [#​10233](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10233)

-   Initial support for the stack-switching proposal has started to land, but it
    is not complete just yet.
    [#​10251](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10251)
    [#​10265](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10265)
    [#​10255](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10255)

##### Changed

-   Pulley's implementation of loads/stores to linear memory has changed to
    better support optimizations and reduction of interpreter opcodes in the
    final binary.
    [#​10154](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10154)

-   Cranelift's verifier now ensures that integers used as address types have the
    correct width.
    [#​10209](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10209)

-   Wasmtime and Cranelift's minimum supported version of Rust is now 1.83.0.
    [#​10264](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10264)

-   Wasmtime now mentions the filename when the input cannot be opened on the CLI.
    [#​10292](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10292)

-   All types are now generated in `component::bindgen!`, even if they're not
    reachable.
    [#​10311](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10311)

-   Tables allocated with the system allocator now use `alloc_zeroed` (aka
    `calloc`) for allocation.
    [#​10313](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10313)

##### Fixed

-   GC: the is-null-or-i31ref checks have been fixed.
    [#​10221](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10221)

-   GC: an incorrect assertion and canonicalized types for runtime usage has been
    fixed.
    [#​10223](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10223)

-   GC: subtype checks for imported globals during instantiation have been fixed.
    [#​10304](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10304)

-   GC: exposing references to wasm in the `gc_alloc_raw` libcall has been fixed.
    [#​10322](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10322)

-   Winch's fuel checks correctly sync fuel before the check now.
    [#​10231](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10231)

-   Winch's treatment of stores and other trapping ops has been fixed on AArch64.
    [#​10201](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10201)

-   Winch's handling of the shadow stack pointer has been fixed on AArch64.
    [#​10263](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10263)

-   Winch's handling of address calculations has been fixed on AArch64.
    [#​10297](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10297)

-   Winch's handling of multivalue return of constants has ben fixed.
    [#​10315](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10315)

</details>

title: chore(deps): update rust crate xmas-elf to 0.10.0 [security]
body:
This PR contains the following updates:

| Package | Type | Update | Change |
|---|---|---|---|
| [xmas-elf](https://redirect.github.com/nrc/xmas-elf) | workspace.dependencies | minor | `0.9.1` -> `0.10.0` |

### GitHub Vulnerability Alerts

#### [GHSA-9cc5-2pq7-hfj8](https://redirect.github.com/nrc/xmas-elf/issues/86)

Affected versions of this crate only validated the `index` argument of `HashTable::get_bucket` and `HashTable::get_chain` against the input-controlled `bucket_count` and `chain_count` fields, but not against the size of the ELF section. As a result, a malformed ELF file could trigger out-of-bounds reads in a consumer of the HashTable API by setting these fields to inappropriately large values that would fall outside the relevant hash table section, and by introducing correspondingly out-of-bounds hash table indexes elsewhere in the ELF file.

---

title: fix: correctly select arena regions
body:
This PR fixes two issues with the arena selection code:
1. When finding a hole to unsuitably large we previously just forgot about the candidate region, essentially wasting it completely. This PR allocates an intermediate vec for all candidates and pushes unsuitable candidates back into that list.
2. the region bounds adjustment code would override itself so that essentially a higher candidate region would completely override the previous arena bounds, essentially wasting the previous lower region

fix: regression of IRQ wakeup

This fixes a regression in the IRQ handling introduced by 429b5c4556416ec79e0ad1c86a3423b7c58d1d72 where cores would treat all IRQs as spurious wakeups

body: This PR fixes a regression in the `scheduler/park` code which would cause tasks to not be woken after timers or interrupts. While it would be great to use this in the future, I can't figure out the exact details of how to correctly do it right now

body: This implements an adapter for the `Fiber` primitive that makes it behave as a `Future` which can then be used to be spawned onto the scheduler

title: chore(deps): update rust crate wasmtime-slab to v32
body:
This PR contains the following updates:

| Package | Type | Update | Change |
|---|---|---|---|
| [wasmtime-slab](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime) | workspace.dependencies | major | `31.0.0` -> `32.0.0` |

---

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>bytecodealliance/wasmtime (wasmtime-slab)</summary>

### [`v32.0.0`](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/releases/tag/v32.0.0)

[Compare Source](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/compare/v31.0.0...v32.0.0)

#### 32.0.0

Released 2025-04-21.

##### Added

-   `{Module,Component}::deserialize_raw` can now be used to deserialize an
    in-memory module while relying on external management of the memory.
    [#​10321](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10321)

-   An initial implementation of wasi-tls has been added.
    [#​10249](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10249)

-   The `wasmtime` CLI now supports hexadecimal integer CLI arguments.
    [#​10360](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10360)

-   Cranelift now supports a `log2_min_function_alignment` flag.
    [#​10391](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10391)

-   A new `wasmtime objdump` subcommand has been added to help explore and debug
    `*.cwasm` files.
    [#​10405](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10405)

-   Support for the pooling allocator has been added to the C API.
    [#​10484](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10484)

-   Support for the guest profiler with the component model has been added.
    [#​10507](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10507)

##### Changed

-   Cranelift `MemFlags` now has a `can_move` flag which restricts whether a load
    or store can be moved.
    [#​10340](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10340)

-   The `.text` size of Pulley `*.cwasm` files should be smaller with less
    padding.
    [#​10285](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10285)

-   The `wasmtime serve` subcommand now implements a graceful shutdown on ctrl-c.
    [#​10394](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10394)

-   Stack maps used for GC are now stored in a serialized binary format that is
    faster to deserialize.
    [#​10404](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10404)

-   The aegraph implementation in Cranelift has been simplified to remove the
    union-find and canonical eclass IDs.
    [#​10471](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10471)

-   The `store_list` and `load_list` helpers have been specialized in components
    for `f32` and `f64`.
    [#​9892](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/9892)

-   Cranelift now removes block params on critical-edge blocks.
    [#​10485](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10485)

-   The `Linker::define_unknown_imports_as_default_values` API now supports
    defining defaults for more kinds of items.
    [#​10500](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10500)

-   Wasmtime now requires Rust 1.84.0 to compile.
    [#​10520](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10520)

##### Fixed

-   Winch compilation of extadd instructions has been fixed.
    [#​10337](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10337)

-   Fix an issue with DRC collector's barriers.
    [#​10371](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10371)

-   Loads on `(ref null none)` that can trap are now performed.
    [#​10372](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10372)

-   Fix reference count management in `AnyRef::from_raw`.
    [#​10374](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10374)

-   An issue with multi-value returns in Winch has been fixed.
    [#​10370](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10370)

-   A panic at compile-time from an overflowing shift has been fixed when
    targeting aarch64.
    [#​10382](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10382)

-   The `wasmtime serve` command no longer panics when `handle` returns before
    calling `set`.
    [#​10387](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10387)

-   Winch compilation of `replace_lane` instructions with floats has been fixed.
    [#​10393](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10393)

-   An invalid integer-shift optimization on vector types has been removed.
    [#​10413](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10413)

-   The DWARF loclist to exprloc optimization has been fixed.
    [#​10400](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10400)

-   Objects in the DRC collector are now transitively dec-ref's when collected.
    [#​10401](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10401)

-   A bug with GC rec gropus and registration in an `Engine` has been fixed.
    [#​10435](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10435)

-   A bug related to GC arrays of GC refs misreported their count of GC edges has
    been fixed.
    [#​10453](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10453)

-   A bug related to appropriately adding stack maps for all GC variables has been
    fixed.
    [#​10456](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10456)
    [#​10468](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10468)

-   A bug with `array.fill` has been fixed.
    [#​10470](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10470)

-   GC structs are no longer reordered to optimize their size to fix subtyping.
    [#​10463](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10463)

-   Panics related to exceptions and components being mixed has been fixed.
    [#​10473](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10473)

-   Winch stack parameter alignment has been fixed.
    [#​10513](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10513)

-   Rendering inline function frames in a trap backtrace has been fixed.
    [#​10523](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10523)

</details>

title: feat: switch to xtask build system
body:
This change switches some of the terrible justfile based build system to a proper Rust xtask one. We should have done this ages ago...

This fixes a number of things:
1. We can now specify build settings (including the target) in a toml profile file. This way we can have different profiles for x86, aarch64, or even variations of the same architecture in the future
2. This finally lets us pass the kernel args properly without just getting in the way

commit.message:
feat: introduce xtask build system

This change switches some of the terrible justfile based build system to a proper Rust xtask one. We should have done this ages ago...

This fixes a number of things:
1. We can now specify build settings (including the target) in a toml profile file. This way we can have different profiles for x86, aarch64, or even variations of the same architecture in the future
2. This finally lets us pass the kernel args properly without just getting in the way

body: This moves the fiber code into its own crate for easier testing, making it a more robust, proper fork of `corosensei`.

commit.message:
feat: add fiber crate

This change adds the `fiber` crate, a fork of corosensei, as the primitive for wasm multitasking.

title: Introduce `abort` library and refactor abort handling
body: Replaced abort functions across libraries with a centralized `abort` library. This centralized function will be unmangled, never inlined and can therefore be used as a breakpoint symbol.

commit.message:
Introduce `abort` library and refactor abort handling

Replaced abort functions across libraries with a centralized `abort` library. This centralized function will be unmangled, never inlined and can therefore be used as a breakpoint symbol.

title: feat: extract `FastRand` into standalone crate
body: Moved the `FastRand` non-cryptographic rng from the kernel to the a standalone crate so we can more easily test, benchmark, and share it throughout the kernel.

commit.message:
feat: extract `FastRand` into standalone crate

Moved the `FastRand` non-cryptographic rng from the kernel to the a standalone crate so we can more easily test, benchmark, and share it throughout the kernel.

title: refactor: simplify `cpu-local` by removing support for destructors
body:
CPU-local storage in k23 doesn't need to support destructors as CPU can never be torn down like threads can.

Removing support for running `Drop` impls of CPU-local values massively simplifies its implementation.

commit.message:
refactor: simplify `cpu-local` by removing support for destructors

CPU-local storage in k23 doesn't need to support destructors as CPU can never be torn down like threads can.

Removing support for running `Drop` impls of CPU-local values massively simplifies its implementation.

This change extracts the kernel's panic.rs logic into a standalone crate (`panic-unwind`) so it can be shared with other library crates such as `fiber`.

title: docs: system startup
body: Add better documentation around system startup

commit.message:
feat: panic-unwind

This change extracts the kernel's panic.rs logic into a standalone crate (`panic-unwind`) so it can be shared with other library crates such as `fiber`.

title: feat(fiber): add support for forced fiber unwind
body:
This change adds support for forcefully unwinding a fiber. This works by unwinding all the way through the fiber stack
and into the callers stack where it will automatically be caught (since we don't actually want to propagate this panic further). 
This helps to ensure that the fiber is correctly cleaned up and all `Drop` impls are correctly called along the way.

commit.message:
feat: panic-unwind

This change extracts the kernel's panic.rs logic into a standalone crate (`panic-unwind`) so it can be shared with other library crates such as `fiber`.

feat(fiber): add support for forced fiber unwind

This change adds support for forcefully unwinding a fiber. This works by unwinding all the way through the fiber stack
and into the callers stack where it will automatically be caught (since we don't actually want to propagate this panic further). 
This helps to ensure that the fiber is correctly cleaned up and all `Drop` impls are correctly called along the way.

title: chore(deps): update rust crate wasmtime-slab to v33 - autoclosed
body:
This PR contains the following updates:

| Package | Type | Update | Change |
|---|---|---|---|
| [wasmtime-slab](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime) | workspace.dependencies | major | `32.0.0` -> `33.0.0` |

---

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>bytecodealliance/wasmtime (wasmtime-slab)</summary>

### [`v33.0.0`](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/releases/tag/v33.0.0)

[Compare Source](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/compare/v32.0.0...v33.0.0)

#### 33.0.0

Released 2025-05-20.

##### Added

-   Cranelift now has initial support for `try_call` and `try_call_indirect`
    instructions, to be used in the future for the WebAssembly exception-handling
    proposal. Wasmtime does not yet implement this proposal yet.
    [#​10510](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10510)
    [#​10557](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10557)
    [#​10593](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10593)

-   Cranelift can now optimize some simple possibly-side-effectful instructions,
    such as division.
    [#​10524](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10524)

-   Wasmtime now supports `--invoke` for components using the WAVE format.
    [#​10054](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10054)

-   Initial support for the Component Model has landed in Wasmtime's C API. Note
    that the API is not yet feature-complete, however.
    [#​10566](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10566)
    [#​10598](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10598)
    [#​10651](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10651)
    [#​10675](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10675)

-   Wasmtime's C++ API is now available from this repository and the
    bytecodealliance/wasmtime-cpp repository has been archived. Additionally the
    monolithic `wasmtime.hh` header file has been split into separate header
    files.
    [#​10582](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10582)
    [#​10600](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10600)

-   Wasmtime's cookbook-style documentation has been expanded.
    [#​10630](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10630)

-   Wasmtime's now supports custom yield behavior when using epoch interrupts.
    [#​10671](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10671)

##### Changed

-   Wasmtime's bindgen now type-checks export functions in the constructor of
    the generated `{Worldname}Pre` or `{Worldname}` structs, rather than at the
    call of the export function.
    [#​10610](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10610)

-   Wasmtime's `component::Component` and `component::Instance` now have consistient
    `get_export` and `get_export_index` methods, which return `(ComponentItem,
    ComponentExportIndex)` and `ComponentExportIndex`, respectively.
    [#​10597](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10597)

-   On failure, `wasmtime serve` gives an internal server error response, rather
    than closing the connection.
    [#​10645](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10645)

-   Cranelift's single-pass allocator has been disabled due to being unable to
    support internal refactorings in preparation for the WebAssembly exceptions
    proposal. Re-enabling this allocator is tracked at
    [regalloc2#217](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/regalloc2/issues/217) for
    those interested.
    [#​10554](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10554)

-   Wasmtime's `{Array,Extern,Struct}Ref` functions will now automatically trigger
    a GC.
    [#​10560](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10560)

-   Wasmtime's GC heaps now use the same translation techniques as linear memories
    meaning they have far fewer bounds-checks than before.
    [#​10503](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10503)

-   Wasmtime's implementation of WASIp2 has moved to `wasmtime_wasi::p2` from the
    root of the crate.
    [#​10073](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10073)

-   Wasmtime will no longer emit calls to Cranelift-defined "libcalls" and instead
    everything goes through Wasmtime's libcall mechanism instead, paving the way
    for a future change for more efficient stack limit checking in wasm. This can
    also improve deserialize-from-disk times and improve page cache usage for
    modules that use libcalls as relocations are no longer necessary.
    [#​10657](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10657)

-   Configuration of caching can now be done through an API instead of exclusively
    through a configuration file. Additionally cache-related APIs in `Config` have
    changed.
    [#​10665](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10665)

-   Resources in the Component Model are now stored in a single table per-instance
    instead of per-type tables. Guests will see a different pattern of index
    allocation but this is not expected to cause any issues at runtime.
    [#​10701](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10701)

##### Fixed

-   Some math intrinsics have been fixed when compiled by Rust 1.87+.
    [#​10534](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10534)

-   Component model libcalls correctly handle platform-specific argument extension
    in ABIs.
    [#​10540](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10540)

-   An off-by-one issue with DWARF debuginfo has been fixed.
    [#​10570](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10570)

-   The `Config::target` method is no longer gated by a `#[cfg]` for an enabled
    compiler, it can be used when only the `runtime` feature is available.
    [#​10618](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10618)

-   An issue with "simulated" DWARF has been fixed.
    [#​10681](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10681)

-   C/C++ headers are now tested that they can be included in isolation, and a
    number of issues have been fixed.
    [#​10694](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10694)

</details>

body:
This PR will move the async task executor out of the kernel into a standalone crate, where it can be better tested. Additionally it will be broken out into components that can be verified & tested individually.

This PR is non-complete but passes basic tests and further work can happen in subsequent PRs.

This closes #422

title: fix: stable task waker identity
body: The `Waker::will_wake` method which is used to optimize waker code across the async executor only performs "shallow" pointer equality checking. This is why usually the waker vtable is stored in a `static`, however I dislike that. IMO the current approach is much cleaner since it correctly inherits the outer generic. The downside of that is we need to use `const` instead of `static` wich would aggressively inline the VTable at callsites. This causes the waker identity to change when calling `.clone()` since the `clone` transitively creates a new reference to the const (and therefore `Waker::will_wake` returns `false` even though it is the functionally the same waker). This *doesn't* affect correctness, it just degrades performance. Using this load-bearing `inline(never)` on the only function that references `Self::WAKER_VTABLE` fixes the inlining issue and preserves a stable identity for the waker.

title: refactor: simplify cpu-local
body:
Now that `cpu-local` statics don't run destructors anymore (#411) I realized the whole `with` construction is pretty unnecessary, there is no need to constrain the lifetime to the callback scope, as soon as the static is initialized it will live for `'static`.

This PR simplifies the cpu-local crate even further by just having `LocalKey` implement `Deref`.

title: refactor: integrate async-exec into kernel
body: This PR moves the async task executor (called `scheduler` until now) out of the kernel and into its own crate. We do this so we can properly test this incredibly nuanced and critical part of the kernel, including tests that just cannot be done inside the kernel such as `loom` and `miri` testing.

commit.message: fix: don't panic on zero stolen tasks
fix: remove unecessary unparks from trap handler

fix: remove park/unpark protocol

The protocol previously implemented by Parker & UnparkToken was designed to prevent spurious wakeups. However, spurious wakeups are not a problem for schedulers
since the queues are a simple way of determining whether the wakeup was spurious or not. And indeed it is desireable to check the queue in these cases, as the 
interrupt that caused the wakeup might have unblocked a task.

Testing
Thanks for your answer on my question with regard to testing in qemu. 

I tried `cargo test -p kasync` but when I run it in my local nix-shell against the main branch
it ends with an error after 13 successfull tests. The message is "result in "process didn't exit successfully: '../debug/deps/kasync-096f0faeb4f90bdd' (signal: 11, SIGSEGV: invalid memory reference))".

I also tried `RUSTFLAGS="--cfg loom" cargo test -p kasync` in the nix-shell against the main branch but it
first gives a compile error. After fixing the complie error (by adding a loom_const_fn on `pub const fn new()'

Please let me know your findings so I can fix any issues...

commit.message:
refactor: create generic trap interface library for x86_64 backend support

As part of the x86_64 backend development (PR #476), this commit refactors trap handling
to be architecture-independent:

- Create dedicated 'trap' library at libs/trap/ for architecture-independent trap types
- Move Trap, Interrupt, and Exception enums from RISC-V-specific code to shared library
- Update RISC-V library to import trap types from the new shared library
- Update kernel trap_handler to use the generic trap interface
- Add trap library to workspace dependencies

This refactoring enables code sharing between RISC-V and future x86_64 implementations,
eliminating duplication and creating a clean architecture-agnostic interface for trap handling.

Verified: RISC-V kernel boots and runs successfully with these changes.

Related to: https://github.com/JonasKruckenberg/k23/pull/476

ðŸ¤– Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>
mv rv trap defs back to scause.rs
PVH works with very big loader
next() was codegen to sse instruction but was not enabled

Key Fixes Made to Enable x86_64 Boot:

  1. kernel/src/arch/x86_64/mod.rs:
    - Fixed FS_BASE MSR: Changed TLS base from 0xffffffc080000000 to 0xffffffc080001000
    - Removed panic in per_cpu_init_late() to allow boot to continue
  2. kernel/src/arch/x86_64/mem.rs:
    - Fixed KERNEL_ASPACE_RANGE: Changed from 0xffff800000000000 to 0xffffffc000000000
    - Implemented AddressSpace::from_active(): Now reads actual CR3 register instead of using 0
  3. kernel/src/arch/x86_64/trap_handler.rs:
    - Removed panic in init(), allowing boot without IDT setup
  4. kernel/src/arch/x86_64/entry.s (new file):
    - Added assembly entry point to properly handle x86_64 calling convention
  5. kernel/src/main.rs:
    - Added x86_64-specific entry point handling
    - Added debug prints to trace boot progress (these are temporary)
    - Added FDT magic number checking for x86_64
  6. Other files: Minor debug additions and x86_64 compatibility fixes
add interactive serial console for shell

## Summary

This PR refactors trap handling to use a shared, architecture-independent interface as part of the ongoing [x86_64 backend development](https://github.com/JonasKruckenberg/k23/pull/476).

### Changes Made

- âœ… **Created dedicated `trap` library** at `libs/trap/` containing generic trap/exception types
- âœ… **Updated RISC-V library** to import shared trap types instead of defining its own
- âœ… **Updated kernel trap_handler** to use the generic trap interface
- âœ… **Added workspace dependencies** for the new trap library

### Architecture Benefits

- **Code Sharing**: Eliminates duplication between RISC-V and future x86_64 implementations
- **Clean Separation**: Proper dependency structure with dedicated trap library
- **Generic Interface**: Architecture-agnostic trap/exception handling foundation

### Verification

- âœ… RISC-V kernel builds successfully
- âœ… RISC-V kernel boots and runs in QEMU
- âœ… All existing functionality preserved

### Context

This refactoring is part of the x86_64 backend development work to create generic interfaces that can be shared between different architectures. By moving trap types to a shared library, we eliminate the architecture-specific imports that were causing compilation issues when building for x86_64.

### Files Changed

- `libs/trap/` - New shared trap library
- `libs/riscv/src/register/scause.rs` - Updated to use shared types
- `kernel/src/mem/trap_handler.rs` - Uses generic trap interface

title: refactor: generalize interrupt controller
body:
## Summary

This PR refactors interrupt controller handling to use a generic, architecture-independent interface as part of the ongoing [x86_64 backend development](https://github.com/JonasKruckenberg/k23/pull/476).

### Problem

The IRQ handling code was directly accessing the RISC-V-specific PLIC (Platform-Level Interrupt Controller) through `cpu.plic.borrow_mut()`, making it impossible to support other architectures like x86_64 which use APIC instead.

### Solution

Created a generic interface that hides architecture-specific interrupt controllers behind a trait:

```rust
pub fn interrupt_controller(&self) -> RefMut<'_, dyn InterruptController>
```

### Changes Made

- âœ… **Added `interrupt_controller()` method** to CPU struct that returns a trait object
- âœ… **Updated `irq.rs`** to use the generic method instead of accessing PLIC directly
- âœ… **Updated trap handler** to use the generic interface with proper dereferencing
- âœ… **Preserved interior mutability** using `RefCell` and `RefMut::map`

### Architecture Benefits

- **Code Sharing**: IRQ handling code is now architecture-agnostic
- **x86_64 Ready**: Can easily add APIC support with the same interface
- **Clean Abstraction**: Interrupt controller details hidden behind trait
- **Type Safety**: Rust's type system ensures correct usage of mutable references

### Implementation Details

The key insight was using `RefMut::map` to convert from `RefCell<Plic>` to `RefMut<dyn InterruptController>`:

```rust
pub fn interrupt_controller(&self) -> RefMut<'_, dyn InterruptController> {
    RefMut::map(self.plic.borrow_mut(), |plic| {
        plic as &mut dyn InterruptController
    })
}
```

### Verification

- âœ… RISC-V kernel builds successfully
- âœ… RISC-V kernel boots and runs in QEMU
- âœ… Interrupt handling works correctly (tested with external interrupts)

### Context

This refactoring is part of the x86_64 backend development work to create generic interfaces that can be shared between different architectures. By abstracting interrupt controller access, we can support both RISC-V's PLIC and x86_64's APIC without duplicating the IRQ handling logic.

### Related Work

- Part of x86_64 backend effort: #476
- Follows similar pattern as trap interface refactoring: #477

ðŸ¤– Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

## Summary
Made the debug output implementation in the tracing writer generic to support multiple architectures.

## Changes
- Created architecture-specific `DebugStream` type alias that switches between:
  - `riscv::hio::HostStream` for RISC-V

## Note
The struct is still named `Semihosting` because semihosting is actually supported on x86 in QEMU as well. The abstraction allows each architecture to implement its preferred debug output mechanism.

The testing infrastructure currently is atrocious. Partly because testing on "embedded" is quite tricky requiring us to build a lot of tooling ourselves, partly because the test matrix is already quite big (different tools, targets, etc.) and partly because we haven't prioritized it enough.

Over the last couple weeks I have pushed a big refactor, breaking out kernel modules into crates in the `lib` folder where they can be tested more effectively. This PR does the second big missing step which is overhauling CI checks and the `just` commands to actually properly run these tests.

This has (unsurprisingly) also uncovered that a number of tests are actually failing quite spectacularly!

title: fix: use strong comparison in `Mutex::try_lock` and introduce `Mutex::try_lock_weak`
body:
This fixes a bug/unexpected behavior and failing Miri test. Previously `try_lock` would use
`compare_exchange_weak` under the hood, but that can spuriously fail *even if* the lock is fully unlocked. This PR changes `try_lock` to use the regular `compare_exchange` and introduces `try_lock_weak` to keep the old behavior (useful if `try_lock_weak` is called in loops)

title: refactor: simplify `kasync`
body:
This PR *massively* simplifies `kasync` making it much more robust, more stable, and easier to test.

The main innovation of this refactor is that now the entire "parking" (i.e. suspending the worker hart when all tasks have been processed or are blocked on IO) has been externalized in a really elegant way (inspired by `smol-rs`): The main worker entrypoint `Worker::run` now returns a `Future` that will drive the main loop when polled. It is now the responsibility of the caller to bring their own `block_on` implementation that can poll this future.

This allows use a different `block_on` impl for tests vs in the kernel. 

The second major change is fully moving the responsibility of driving the timer to the consumer too. Previously `Timer` was field on the `Executor`, but consumers are fully free to handle the timer however works best for them. In tests we use a separate "reactor thread" while in the kernel we rely on timer interrupts like previously.

fix: correctly wake up HART on interrupt in trap handler

title: debug: Fix page allocator index calculation
body:
The original code used `usize::MAX << arch::VIRT_ADDR_BITS` to calculate the base of the kernel address space. This works by coincidence for RISC-V but fails for x86_64:

For RISC-V (38-bit virtual addresses):
```
riscv64::KERNEL_ASPACE_BASE = 0xffffffc000000000
riscv64::VIRT_ADDR_BITS = 38
usize::MAX << riscv64::VIRT_ADDR_BITS = 0xffffffc000000000 // same as KERNEL_ASPACE_BASE
```

For x86_64 (48-bit virtual addresses):
```
x86_64::KERNEL_ASPACE_BASE = 0xffffffc000000000
x86_64::VIRT_ADDR_BITS = 48
usize::MAX << x86_64::VIRT_ADDR_BITS = 0xffff000000000000 // different with KERNEL_ASPACE_BASE
```

comments.body: Ahh hehe, this one is on me. You must set `VIRT_ADDR_BITS` to *one less* than the "address bitness" for the math to work out. Maybe `VIRT_ADDR_BITS` is a bad name, but it essentially means "the highest usable bit of an address". So for RISCV Sv39 which is a 39 bit addressing system we set `VIRT_ADDR_BITS = 38` and for standard x86 you should set `VIRT_ADDR_BITS = 47`.

title: refactor: arch-agnostic page level

comments.body:
Question: what's the exact issue you're seeing on x86_64 without this change? Because theoretically this should already work as expected. 

The page allocator currently divides the upper half of virtual memory into `arch::PAGE_TABLE_ENTRIES / 2` (so 256 for both RISCV Sv39 and 512 for x86_64 PML4) number of chunks. The idea is that each of those chunks represents a top-level page (so 1GiB on RISCV and 512GB on x86). When allocating a `Layout`, we first pick a contiguous set of top-level pages to fit the layout (most likely just one) and then pick a random offset according to the `Layout` within that top level page.

Your current change maintains correct behavior on 3-level MMUs, would break on 2-or-less-level MMUs, but more importantly would only utilize the *lower half* of the kernel space on 4-level MMUs. This obviously isn't great from an ASLR entropy perspective, but also means during kernel allocation we essentially waste half the available virtual memory.

So my question: What's the error you're seeing? Can this be solved differently somehow (again, I *think* this should work already?) otherwise we might have to redo the allocator entirely.

title: chore(deps): update rust crate wasmtime-slab to v34
body:
This PR contains the following updates:

| Package | Type | Update | Change |
|---|---|---|---|
| [wasmtime-slab](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime) | workspace.dependencies | major | `33.0.0` -> `34.0.0` |

---

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>bytecodealliance/wasmtime (wasmtime-slab)</summary>

### [`v34.0.1`](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/releases/tag/v34.0.1)

[Compare Source](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/compare/v34.0.0...v34.0.1)

#### 34.0.1

Released 2025-06-24.

##### Fixed

- Fix a panic with host-defined tables/globals and concrete reference
  types.
  [#​11103](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/11103)

### [`v34.0.0`](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/releases/tag/v34.0.0)

[Compare Source](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/compare/v33.0.1...v34.0.0)

#### 34.0.0

Released 2025-06-20.

##### Added

- Support for SIMD in the Pulley interpreter can now be disabled at compile-time
  to shrink the size of the final binary.
  [#​10727](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10727)

- The C API now has `wasmtime_trap_new_code` to create a `wasm_trap_t` from
  its code.
  [#​10765](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10765)

- Winch's support for x86\_64 is now classified with tier 1 support in Wasmtime.
  [#​10755](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10755)

- Winch's support for aarch64 now implements stack checks to pass many more spec
  tests.
  [#​10763](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10763)

- Cranelift's s390x backend now has full support for the `f128` type.
  [#​10774](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10774)

- Wasmtime's C API for the component model has initial support for calling
  functions.
  [#​10697](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10697)
  [#​10841](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10841)
  [#​10858](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10858)
  [#​10864](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10864)
  [#​10877](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10877)

- The `wasmtime wast` command now has a `--generate-dwarf` flag to show
  filename/line number information for backtraces.
  [#​10780](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10780)

##### Changed

- The shape of `bindgen!`-generated `add_to_linker` functions has changed with
  the removal of `GetHost` and replacement of a `HasData` trait. For more
  information see the associated PR.
  [#​10770](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10770)

- Wasmtime's `Store<T>` now requires that `T: 'static`. This is done in
  preparation for merging WASIp3 work to the main repository with some more
  information on the associated PR.
  [#​10760](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10760)

- The `wasmtime::component::Instance::instance_pre` method is now public.
  [#​10761](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10761)

- Wasmtime and Cranelift's minimnum supported version of Rust (MSRV) is now
  1.85.0.
  [#​10785](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10785)

- Cranelift's `debugtrap` on aarch64 now generates `brk #​0xf000` for debuggers
  to recognize it.
  [#​10813](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10813)

- The wasi-http implementation no longer generates a trap if the handle to
  receive the response on the host is dropped early.
  [#​10833](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10833)

- The `wasmtime serve` command will now send some boilerplate descriptive HTML
  on a 500 server error instead of nothing.
  [#​10851](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10851)

- A significant amount of work has gone into the new assembler for the x64
  backend. Too many PRs to list here but progress continues apace at defining
  all machine instructions in a standalone crate.

- Cranelift will now reject unimplemented big-endian loads/stores on backends
  that do not implement this functionality.
  [#​10863](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10863)

- The `wasmtime explore` generated HTML handles large modules better now.
  [#​10892](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10892)

- Wasmtime's internal representation of `wasmtime::Func` has changed and a
  previous optimization of `Func::call` has been lost. If affected it'd
  recommended to use `Func::call_unchecked` instead or to open an issue.
  [#​10897](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/10897)

### [`v33.0.1`](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/releases/tag/v33.0.1)

[Compare Source](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/compare/v33.0.0...v33.0.1)

#### 33.0.1

Released 2025-06-24.

##### Fixed

- Fix a panic with host-defined tables/globals and concrete reference
  types.
  [#​11103](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/11103)

</details>

---

### Configuration

 ```bash
 just run profile/x86_64/qemu.toml -- args0 args1 ...

## After

just run profile/x86_64/qemu.toml -- args0 args1 ...

cargo xtask run profile/x86_64/qemu.toml -- args0 args1 ...
```

title: rustfmt `use` items
body:
Adds a `rustfmt.toml` file with the following configuration:

```toml
group_imports = "StdExternalCrate"
imports_granularity = "Module"
```

Defining a stable ordering of `use` items which are traditionally quite messy

#### What's Changed

- Fix Typos in Documentation Comments by [@​vtjl10](https://redirect.github.com/vtjl10) in [https://github.com/bytecodealliance/wasm-tools/pull/2239](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasm-tools/pull/2239)

- Extract `json-from-wast` to its own crate by [@​alexcrichton](https://redirect.github.com/alexcrichton) in [https://github.com/bytecodealliance/wasm-tools/pull/2247](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasm-tools/pull/2247)
- Return `FrameKind` in `FramStack::current_frame` by value by [@​Robbepop](https://redirect.github.com/Robbepop) in [https://github.com/bytecodealliance/wasm-tools/pull/2248](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasm-tools/pull/2248)
- Optimize `OperatorsReader` control stack by [@​Robbepop](https://redirect.github.com/Robbepop) in [https://github.com/bytecodealliance/wasm-tools/pull/2241](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasm-tools/pull/2241)
- Update publish script by [@​alexcrichton](https://redirect.github.com/alexcrichton) in [https://github.com/bytecodealliance/wasm-tools/pull/2249](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasm-tools/pull/2249)
- Fix spelling wit\_encoder::RenderOpts.ident\_count to indent\_count by [@​MendyBerger](https://redirect.github.com/MendyBerger) in [https://github.com/bytecodealliance/wasm-tools/pull/2252](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasm-tools/pull/2252)
- wasm-tools print: add option to print operand stack between instructions by [@​keithw](https://redirect.github.com/keithw) in [https://github.com/bytecodealliance/wasm-tools/pull/2251](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasm-tools/pull/2251)
- Update various workspace dependencies/lints/etc. by [@​alexcrichton](https://redirect.github.com/alexcrichton) in [https://github.com/bytecodealliance/wasm-tools/pull/2254](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasm-tools/pull/2254)

- fix: added musl builds x86\_64 and aarch64 by [@​thomas9911](https://redirect.github.com/thomas9911) in [https://github.com/bytecodealliance/wasm-tools/pull/2259](https://redirect.github.com/bytecodealliance/wasm-tools/pull/2259)
